name: alejandro
text:
Guys, quick highlight of 3 development principles I believe will be key for us to keep at the forefront of everything we do:
• *We only do a few things, but we do them better than anyone else.* We should be hyper focused and do the thing we focus on to an excellent standard. 
• *We stick to the basics.* Nobody really cares about a fancy AI pipeline or a stunning UX *if* it doesn't solve the customer's actual problem. 
• *We over-communicate.* This is both verbally in meetings but also in written form via Slack and documentation. Can't stress how important excellent and detailed documentation is for everything we do.

sub-messages.name: alejandro

sub-messages.name: alejandro
sub-messages.text: How did we compare both out of curiosity?

sub-messages.name: Razi Khan
sub-messages.text:
Vapi provides a ready-made solution which is why they charge more per minute but with limited flexibility.

And it is highly likely that Vapi is a wrapper around LiveKit itself.

By dealing with livekit we can have control over the STT, TTS, Livekit server and can minimize the latency and other issues as well. Although it requires some learning curve but longer run it is much better option.

sub-messages.text: Any thoughts why livekit would also perform better than vapi if its potentially a wrapper around it?

sub-messages.name: Razi Khan
sub-messages.text:
We can host our own livekit dedicated server - that will keep the latency in check.

Vs

vapi just gives you endpoint and doesn't let you choose your server.


Same in case of TTS and STT and LLM (specially in case of local hosted opensource LLM )

sub-messages.text: @Moses Ubah Suggested to have one repo for front and backend. In my opinion to keep things clean I want to have separate repos for backend and keep them segregated and independent.

sub-messages.name: alejandro
sub-messages.text: @Razi Khan curious if multiple repos for MVP is overkill and whether we should have a monorepo for now and then spilt down the line?

sub-messages.name: Razi Khan
sub-messages.text: Can do but was suggesting for better code management

sub-messages.name: alejandro
sub-messages.text: I get that, but curious of added complexity now. Curious what you think of added complexity/isolation now vs. gained independence/code management?

sub-messages.name: Razi Khan
sub-messages.text:
I see the concern about added complexity with multiple repos for the MVP. However, having separate repos for the front and backend offers some key benefits:

1. *Better Code Management*: Independent repos make it easier to manage and pinpoint issues.
2. *Scalability*: It simplifies scaling different parts of the application as we grow.
3. *Deployment Flexibility*: We can deploy updates and fixes independently.
4. *Clear Separation*: It keeps our architecture cleaner and more modular.
As for complexity, setting up two repos is straightforward. We can configure CI/CD once and set endpoints in the config, with no need for frequent changes after that. While a monorepo simplifies things initially, separate repos offer better long-term organization and flexibility. The approach supports both our immediate needs and future growth.

name: alejandro
text:
Hey all, excited to kickoff sprint 3 today. 2 more weeks left in our 1-month development process, and we'll then figure out the plan post launch since that really is only the true starting point. Since we have a lot in motion wanted to highlight some key milestones for us for this and next week:

_*This week:*_
• *Design*: complete hi-fi for full Manager and Rep accounts (includes Simulate and Track)
• *Frontend*: complete Manager account with full integration to backend, maybe some progress with rep as well
• *Backend*/*ML*: nail down simulation workflow (i.e. simulations are of enough quality/latency), connect with frontend of manager account, maybe start working on feedback piece
_*Next week:*_
• *Design*: complete superadmin account (main thing here will be the persona/scorecard editing)
• *Frontend*: complete rep account (fully integrated to backend) and superadmin (fully integrated to backend)
• *Backend*/*ML*: nail down the feedback generation piece and integrate to superadmin workflow (main thing here will be the persona/scorecard editing)
cc @Daniel Afolabi @Moses Ubah @Razi Khan, please ask questions, clarify if something doesn't make sense or seems realistic

sub-messages.name: Razi Khan
sub-messages.text: @alejandro I have figured out the issue. The nginx stopped. I am working on it. Server will be working in few minutes.

sub-messages.name: alejandro
sub-messages.text: Why did it stop? Also did we institute a reverse proxy? I thought we fixed cors issues a different way

sub-messages.name: Razi Khan
sub-messages.text: @alejandro It was not able to pick some ssl certificates.

sub-messages.name: Razi Khan
sub-messages.text: Yes, we are using Nginx. I thought I had communicated that with you. Currently, I have added CORS settings in the Flask application. Although it is also possible to handle this in Nginx, but I don't think it's necessary.

sub-messages.name: alejandro
sub-messages.text: Why did we add Nginx if we still use CORS settings?

sub-messages.name: alejandro
sub-messages.text: "It was not able to pick some ssl certificates." how come the issue wasn't picked up when it crashed and how do we know this won't happen again

sub-messages.name: Razi Khan
sub-messages.text: Setting up SSL in Nginx is convenient, which is one of the reasons we are using it. Additionally, we have the option to add CORS settings in Nginx if needed. Currently, we have implemented CORS settings in the Flask application, but having Nginx allows us the flexibility to manage these settings in the future if necessary.

sub-messages.name: Razi Khan
sub-messages.text: There was an issue with the permissions of the directory where the certificates were placed. To prevent this problem from happening again, I have set the appropriate permissions, ensuring that this issue won't recur.

sub-messages.name: alejandro
sub-messages.text: Do we have an alert system for nginx stopping? Seems like tabelestakes to have it

name: alejandro
text:
Just spoke to each one of you <!channel>. Wanted to thank you all for the great work so far, we built something really cool in a very short time window. There's a good movie I watched yesterday called "The Boys in the Boat" which is about a true story of an 8-person rowing team and all their sudden successes. In the movie they highlight how the most important piece behind their success is not how good each rower was, but how the boat moved as 1 not as 8 individual people. I think a lot of our success so far has come from moving as 1, not 4 individuals, through all the standups and challenges. We all leaned into a team mentality and it clearly paid off.

Their will be less dev and design work over the next few months. We'll still want to problem solve and add key features we identify based on customer feedback. The main focus will be however on GTM, i.e. selling what we have, which I'll be leading. I'll for sure be using Ekho to practice. Our goal there is to get 2-3 more paying betas this year, with 2+ of those converting to annual customers. This should give us enough traction to hopefully transition full-time by end of year/early next.

This is only the start. Thanks for the hard work.

Quote of the day (from the book The Boys in the Boat): "All were merged into one smoothly working machine; they were, in fact, a poem of motion, a symphony of swinging blades.”

text: Hey <!channel>,sorry for the radio silence. Customer has been doing well. Been fully focused on sales since we need to get new customers through the door. I've been testing the idea of colleges, as an AI-powered career coach. Been seeing some good initial results. Will keep you all posted on progress, hope you're all doing well!

name: Daniel Afolabi
text: Great work Ale :rocket:

name: alejandro
text: Hey all, wanted to share another update. Still working 110% on the sales side, so don't foresee any development/design work in the near future. If that changes I'll let you know asap. My goal is still to get enough traction where there's enough full-time dev work, but that won't happen in near future (i.e. next few months). If I can help in the meantime with reviews on Upwork or being a reference please let me know.
